meanings.definition: The state or condition of being old-fashioned or outdated.
meanings.sent1: In the fogydom of the past, people used typewriters instead of computers.
meanings.sent2: Her reluctance to try new technology showed her fogydom.
meanings.sent3: Grandpa's insistence on using a flip phone is a prime example of fogydom.
meanings.sent4: The antique shop was a fogydom paradise, filled with relics of the past.
meanings.sent5: The dusty old library exuded a sense of fogydom with its ancient books.

meanings.definition: The beliefs or practices of a conservative or traditionalist.
meanings.sent1: His fogydom led him to oppose any changes to the school curriculum.
meanings.sent2: She held onto her fogydom, refusing to adapt to modern trends.
meanings.sent3: The fogydom of the town council resulted in resistance to new ideas.
meanings.sent4: His fogydom was like a shield against the winds of change.
meanings.sent5: The museum displayed the fogydom of the past through its exhibits.

meanings.definition: A group or society of individuals who resist change or progress.
meanings.sent1: The fogydom in the village council hindered development projects.
meanings.sent2: The fogydom at the meeting was evident in their reluctance to embrace new ideas.
meanings.sent3: The fogydom of the group made them the last to adopt modern technology.
meanings.sent4: Their fogydom was a barrier to innovation and growth.
meanings.sent5: The fogydom of the committee slowed down the implementation of new policies.
